item.description:
Designing a "wonder zoo" is not easy as it seems. First, you must choose a theme, then find the most beautiful animals, and finally attract crowds of enthusiastic visitors!

In WonderZoo, you do just this by each round choosing a tile from among those on the table, then placing it on your personal game board, with paths needing to continue from one tile to the next. You can also carry out the action shown on the tile that you just added, such as adding a visitor to your zoo, moving a visitor, moving an enclosure, or becoming first player in the next round.

When you can place no more tiles in your zoo, the game ends for you, but other players might continue depending on the status of their zoo. Once everyone has completed their zoos, players score 1 point for each visitor next to an enclosure tile, and whoever has the most points wins.

You can increase the difficulty level of WonderZoo by having players start with certain squares blocked, and you can add advanced scoring rules as well, with the yellow visitor granting 2 points when next to a yellow enclosure.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
VOID is a work of art created for the "Is This a Game?" exhibition held in the Akihabara section of Tokyo from May 29 to June 3, 2018.

VOID includes many strange tiles, along with dice and a marker, but it contains no specific rules on how to use these components to play a game. Well, sort of — you use these materials as you wish to create a game scene, then you take a photo or video of that fabricated game scene and upload it to whatever social networking services seem appropriate for you and your fellow players using the hashtag #voidgame. Whoever receives the most "likes" on their post wins.

Have fun with television's funniest group of friends in this take-anywhere Seinfeld trivia game. See how much you remember about Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer, and their friends and families as you try to be the first player to collect 5 cards and win.

Every card features two questions, including one extra-challenging question for the super fans of the show.

Features episodes from all nine seasons.

Contents: 149 game cards with 298 trivia questions, rules card.

Note: Not the same as Seinfeld Trivia Game which features 600 questions on 300 cards as well as a game board and other components.

In Top Gamer every player wants to be the best boardgames' gamer. This game uses Games Cards system and simulates boardgaming.

Every player trains his brain by playing board games during game parties. Playing in every game gives some experience to him, and player chooses which his level of game type or game mechanism to raise. After 2 game parties all players try to win the next 8 players (bots replace absent players) game tournament. To win tournament player must have higher total of his levels for type and mechanism of tournament game. The best 3 players of tournament get 3, 2 or 1 victory points. After 10th round player with the most points is top gamer.

The medieval strategy game!

Giddy-up! The castle is under attack! Choose a horse and follow the winding paths to save the price, princess, and precious treasures - each with their own point values. Race along the paths until all of the people and treasures are safe from invaders. The one who rescues the most treasure points wins the game!

In Scotland Yard, one of the players takes on the role of Mr. X. His job is to move from point to point around the map of London taking taxis, buses or subways. The detectives — that is, the remaining players acting in concert — move around similarly in an effort to move into the same space as Mr. X. But while the criminal's mode of transportation is nearly always known, his exact location is only known intermittently throughout the game.

Scotland Yard: Tokyo features the same gameplay as Scotland Yard, but with the detectives and Mr. X running around Tokyo instead of London. When only 1-3 detectives are on the board, an extra "police" figure is placed on the board that does not require tickets for movement.

Scotland Yard: Tokyo appears to have been produced in conjunction with the Japanese game retailer Sugorokuya.

Shake up the 36 dungeon cubes, flip the timer, uncover and compete! In this epic real time tabletop dungeon crawler players have four minutes to draw routes through the dungeon on their 6x6 grids on their score sheets. After, players add up their scores from all grids they've filled out this round and the highest total score wins! players gain more points per run the more spaces they cross and the more enemies they defeat and treasures they collect.

—description from the publisher

In this turn based follow up to the real time dungeon crawler Nonstop Dungeon take control of your favorite cat character and control them in the dungeon with your personal video game controller player mat. Use the DPAD sticks to claim routes on the map. Complete quests by collecting items in the dungeon to earn upgrades for your controller such as a joystick or shoulder buttons. Steal Dragon Eggs to gain VP or purchase quests. When a player has filled up their personal tv screen with quests or when all dragon eggs are claimed from the bank the game is over with the highest scoring player winning!

—description from the publisher

Please Pass the Mustard! is a fast-action card game for 2 to 6 players, ages 8 and up, in which hungry eaters select the foods they want to eat and then shop for the mustards that go with them.

The first player to place five different foods on his or her "dishes" and also play the five paired mustards wins the game.

Players roll dice to determine an action for their turn, and then play and draw cards representing various dishes, mustards, wild cards and ketchup, which is used to ruin other players dishes.

name.value: Total Monstrosities the Card Game: Original Orange

item.description:
"Total Monstrosities the Card Game - Original Orange" is a game for 1 – 6 players that takes roughly 5 – 15 minutes.

The aim of the game is to win the specified amount of Totalmon Cards decided before the game starts. You win Totalmon cards by having the strongest overall Totalmon at the end of a round. Use Buff and Support Cards to raise your total, or better yet, Mutate your Totalmon into stronger Totalmon to gain the edge. The first player to reach the specified amount of Totalmon Cards wins the game.

—description from the publisher

Point! Set! Match!

Play volleyball match on the board. Receive the ball, pass it, attack and score a point!
“Siatka” is a dynamic game that simulates a volleyball match. Players decide how to play a ball, use individual players' skills or... to surprise opponent with quick attack from the second line.

The box contains simple basic rules for beginners and advanced rules for experienced players.

A cooperative game for small children!

You are going to the Dinosaur Park with your family. But what is this? Dinosaurs scattered around the park and the meteor shower has just been announced on the radio.
Help the dinosaurs return to their catwalks before a cosmic storm begins.

Dinosaur Park is a game that evolves with children - after defeating the basic level you can struggle with more difficult tasks.

Fire! Car accident! Robbery!

In the game Na ratunek! (To the rescue!), players send their emergency vehicles to various accidents. They earn a victory point for each successful action. Players train memory, perception and learn how to react in dangerous situations.
 "Na ratunek!” is a game from the series "Pocket game for pocket money", which contains interesting family games for children 6 +.

Excitement in a prehistoric period! The saber-toothed tiger clan is looking for a new leader, but which one of you can best take care of the clan in Honga and prove to be the most worthy leader?

There are multiple ways to prove your worth: gather supplies, comb through the dark forest, pay homage to the old nature gods, attract mammoths, and successfully trade with other clans. But! No matter how busy you are with these tasks, you can never forget Honga! Whenever you ignore the local saber-toothed tiger, he will come and eat your food — and getting rid of him can turn out to be tough.

Honga is an action selection resource management game for 2-5 players, age 8+, set in the prehistoric period. Players take turns playing their action card to the central board, paying careful attention to where they place it, and how it's rotated. The number of hands pointing to an action space determines how many times you may use that action. Gather resources and use them to complete trade agreements, lure mammoths to the tribe herd, and pay homage to the old nature gods. But! If you don't make sure that at least one action point is allocated to Honga's den, he'll come steal food from you! Players must balance between keeping Honga at bay and using their limited action points effectively.

With multiple paths to victory, light player interaction, and a 45 minute play time, this game will have you coming back again and again to play with Honga, the local saber-tooth tiger that's really just a big kitty at heart.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The Official Loaded Questions Party Game based on The Big Lebowski

HILARIOUS GAMEPLAY - In this adult party game for 4-6 players, choose your favorite answer and guess 'who wrote which answer' to 180 open-ended Loaded Questions inspired by The Big Lebowski

NO TRIVIA - Whether you have seen the cult classic film 0, 1 or 100 times, your enjoyment level and chance of winning are not an issue. It’s just a party game, man.

EASY RULES - This is not 'Nam, there are rules! But these rules are simple, man, so you can enjoy your Game Night right after opening the box.

ORIGINAL ARTWORK - All of the quality components, including the large format game cards, feature beautiful, original artwork by Dave Perillo.

OFFICIAL LICENSE - The Dude would approve.

—description from the publisher

A 3-6 player card game about killing real-world game designer Lee Garvin. Or saving him, you can win either way. Basic play involves color combinations of amusingly illustrated Harm and Help cards to manipulate the overall state of play.

Get rid of all the Harm tokens you have and you win. If someone else has too many, Lee bites the dust, and the winner is the one with the fewest tokens. So, you can either frame someone else for Lee's demise if you think you will end the round with the best game position, or simply try to improve your own position without making too many enemies.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The hilarious adult party version of the classic ‘who said what’ game.

Features 308 new and classic Adult Loaded Questions, all new design, and added game play features/components for a laughter-filled Game Night

Questions include: What is an instant mood killer? / What word sounds dirty…but isn’t? / What TV show would you watch if it included full nudity

Let’s Say It’s Your Turn…


 Flick the spinner, pick the next card, and read aloud the corresponding question. (Let’s say the question is “What would you NOT want to find in your partner’s bedside drawer?)
 All other players write a personal answer for the question on their answer sheets, which are then collected and read aloud by the player to your right.
 After hearing all of the answers, choose your favorite and match which player wrote which answer. Match correctly and pick one of the highly desirable VIP cards. The player who wrote your favorite answer also wins one of these cards. The first lucky player to collect 8 VIP cards wins the game!


2017 UPDATE: How To Win and VIP cards are updated in this version

—description from the publisher

The Family/Friends Version of the Classic Game of 'Who Said What'

If you never owned this classic game of 'who wrote what' or need to update your older copy, this NEW edition is the one to get.

Features 880 new and classic Loaded Questions, all new design, and added game play features for a lifetime of memorable game nights.

Questions include: What is something you only need one of? / What word would people never use to describe you? / What is your most useless talent?

This core Loaded Questions game is perfect for families and adults.

Let’s Say It’s Your Turn…


 Read aloud the Loaded Question that matches the colored space you’re on. (Let’s say the question is “What is something you would love to do every day of your life?)
 All other players write a personal answer for the question on their answer sheets, which are collected and read aloud by the player to your right.
 After hearing all of the answers, match which player wrote which answer. Advance one space for every correct match. The first player to reach the WIN space wins the game!


—description from the publisher

Work on 3 words simultaneously.

You will take cards one at a time, adding each card to one of 3 lines. Try to turn each line into a word. Score much more for longer words.

Will you just aim for the easy points, or will you burn cards waiting for a higher-scoring word?

This game can be played by many people simultaneously. If you have a 'caller' telling everyone what card to play next, it becomes Muckell. After all, 'many a mickell makes a muckell'.

—description from the designer

name.value: Super Mario Match: The Crazy Cube Game
Harry Potter Match: The Crazy Cube game

item.description: Top Trumps Match has loads of Nintendo cubes and characters. Open the Game Grid and see if you can make a row of 5 matching Super Mario Images. Will you get the character you need? Will your opponent spoil your chances? Will you take the Match with the special Top Trumps cards? It’s great for strategy, memory and recognition and with the all-in-one carry case, you can take Top Trumps Match anywhere!

12 eggs are placed on a plastic straw base in a circle with the smaller end pointed to the center. Each player takes turns grabbing an egg while attempting to avoid unbalancing the chicken and awakening her. The last player to not awaken the chicken is the winner.

Détective Mathéo is a mathematics card game. The box contains three games: additions, subtractions, and multiplications.

Cards are displaying calculations on one side and results on the other side.

Players choose a card set, shuffle the cards, and put the pile between them with the calculations visible. They flip over the topmost card which now shows results and place this card next to the pile. The aim is to be the first to find the only calculations whose result is on the result card.

The player who first finds the right pair gives the result aloud and then the associated calculation. If they are correct, he then wins the "Results" card which is worth one point. If they are wrong, the are out for the rest of that round.

At the end of the game, one card will be left on the table, the player who has won the most card is the winner of the game.

Badly Drawn Death is a quick, brutal and stupid battle card game where you try to kill your friends in silly ways. For 2-5 players, the aim of the game is to be the last person standing to win. You do this by building your defences and attacking your opponents.

72 unique cards make up the game, each featuring a humorous and sometimes downright outrageous drawing. From the Cake of Death to the Badly Driven Tank, you'll be laughing as you rain death down on all of your friends!

You'll also find plenty of opportunities for picking on other players back-stabbing at the opportune moment. Badly Drawn Death is both brutal and unexpected in its gameplay. You never know what will happen next and nobody is ever safe!

—description from the designer

name.value: Mortain Aug44: Old Hickory vs. the SS

item.description:
My devilish little print-and-play regimental/kampfgruppe level game about the desperate German counterattack in southern Normandy - "Normandy's Switzerland" - west toward Avranches and the sea against U.S. 1st Army units, to cut off our (especially Patton's 3rd Army's) breakout into all France. 18 8-hour turns, 7-12Aug44. 23 U.S. (eventually) + 4 tac air vs. 12 or 13 German units. 1 mile/1.6 kilometers per hex and pro-defense combat results, because of the dense, compartmentalizing terrain, which was still bocage as well. Includes divisional and corps artillery and Allied fighterbomber/Jaegerbomber/"Jabo" airpower. There is the 50% possibility of German General der Panzertruppen Gerhard Graf von Schwerin's historical (patriotic) anti-Hitler treachery, which held back 116. PzDiv in the north for 48 crucial hours and profoundly crippled Fall (Operation) Luettich.

Allied player must choose to exit units in the south for victory points or use them instead to stop the German schwerpunkten (from advancing and getting victory points). This is a tight, nerve-wracking game requiring both players to claw for every victory point.

If (von Schwerin has been relieved/arrested and) 116. PzDiv is unleashed, the U.S. player must patiently and enduringly play the long game to wear down German units and catch up by then eliminating them.

—description from the designer

name.value: Devil Core Tactics: Strategy RPG Card Wars

item.description:
Devil Core Tactics is a diceless strategy RPG card game for 2 players. Build your battlefield, summon your allies and enter into the war of the gods as you battle against each other. This is the core set and includes everything needed to get started.

This set includes :

 Sacred Cross Deck x30 Cards (In Custom Sacred Cross Tuckbox)
 Crimson Nobles Deck x30 Cards (In Custom Crimson Nobles Tuckbox)
 8x10 Sinosha Battlemaps x30 (15 Per Deck) (Double Sided)
 Devil Core Tactics : Rules
 Battle Record Sheet x2




—description from the designer

After the defeats of Auerstaedt and Jena, Prussia collapsed but has not yet surrendered. Their Russian ally arrives by the east to defy Napoléon. The tough Polish campaign is beginning.

When the game meets History

Napoléon 1807 is a game at the crossroads of History and simulation. It uses the same game system as Napoléon 1806.

With Napoléon 1807, in 1 to 2 hours, two players will relive the clashes between Russians and French in the heart of winter 1806-1807 in Poland. Three campaigns are proposed that retrace the terrible events that will culminate in the famous battles of Pultusk, Eylau and Friedland.

Napoléon 1807 is intended for seasoned grognads as well as for young conscripts who want to try a new playfull sensation. Strategy, anticipation, decision, are the engines of the Napoléon 1807 game system.

name.value: Deck Derby: A Dead Seas Racing Game

item.description:
Deck Derby is a fast paced racing game in the Dead Seas fantasy realm. Racers use unique dice drafting mechanics to upgrade and win!

In Deck Derby each racer has a "Favored Number" and a "Favored Color". All players roll their dice and place them into a dice pool. One at a time players draft the dice there racers need to perform actions. Some of these actions won't require any certain number or color, some will require your preferred number, some will require you preferred color, and for game changing abilities the player must have both their preferred number and color. Racers will use their actions to speed themselves up, slow down other racers, or attack if the race is close.

—description from the publisher

For centuries, the legendary wingaling dragon Trogdor the Burninator has terrorized the peasant kingdom of Peasantry with his scorching flames and greased-up beefy arm. Now, he has descended from the mountains once again and will not stop until he burninates the entire countryside and all those unfortunate enough to get in his way!

A cult of hooded creepos calling themselves the Keepers of Trogdor have devoted their lives to aiding the mighty dragon in his quest for total and complete burnination. That's where YOU come in!

In Trogdor!: The Board Game, you and up to five friends — or maybe people you just paid to come over — take on the roles of these acolytes of the Burninator, each with their own unique abilities and magical items. Take turns guiding Trogdor on his destructive lost weekend around Peasantry. Help him avoid pesky knights and archers, devour peasants, burninate the countryside, and, of course, the thatched roof COTTAGES!!

—description from the publisher

Snowdonia is a competitive or solitaire worker placement game, lovingly crafted around the idea of building railways in Wales, and – with multiple other scenarios – around the world.

Snowdonia: Deluxe Master Set contains the Snowdonia base game as well as all previously released promo cards and scenarios, along with five new scenarios: The Bluebell Railway, The Qinghai-Tibet Railway, The Mount Hakone Electric Railway, The Wye Valley Tourer, and The Malta Railway. This set also includes an automa (Botdell), designed by Dávid Turczi, along with a number of designer trains which are new to the Deluxe Master Set.

Contains:
 
Snowdonia
Snowdonia: Bayerische Zugspitzbahn
Snowdonia: Britannia Bridge
Snowdonia: Candace Camille
Snowdonia: Card 31 of 30
Snowdonia: Essen 2012 Promo Cards
Snowdonia: Jungfraubahn & Mount Washington
Snowdonia: Lost Train Promo Card
Snowdonia: Mrs Larkin's Washing Machine
Snowdonia: Pen-y-Gwryd Hotel
Snowdonia: Puffing Billy
Snowdonia: Rolling Stock #1
Snowdonia: Seasons
Snowdonia: Supply Wagon/Cannon
Snowdonia: The Battlepuppy Express
Snowdonia: The Daffodil Line (the full set of cards found in the first print run; there were less cards for it in the Trans-Australian Railway & The Daffodil Line printing)
Snowdonia: The Lord Mayor's State Coach
Snowdonia: The Necropolis Railway & Neuhauser Bockerlbahn
Snowdonia: The North Pole & The Great Bridge Scrapyard Promo Tile
Snowdonia: The Siege of Petersburg / The Channel Tunnel 1881
Snowdonia: Trans-Australian Railway & The Daffodil Line
Snowdonia: Wagons Expansion

Also includes promo cards that were previously print and play only (these were Kickstarter stretch goals):
Princess Margaret Rose
The Bought At Auction Loco
No. 11 Prototype Engine
The Breakdown Crane
The Utility Loco
Santa's Sleigh
Krampus
The Camoflaged Loco

The Great Old One
The Coal Train
The Downbound Train
Sen's Train
The Scarecrow
The Falkland Island Express
The Birthday Train
Terraforming Engine

Thomas the W*** Engine
The Unreliable Engine
The Coal Train
The Luggage (and this one will be altered, sorry)
The Son of God
The Guvnor's Engine
The Love Train
Conveyor Belt.

AND everything else...EVERYTHING Tony ever published/designed for campaigns/scribbled on envelopes etc!

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Snowdonia: Share and Share Alike / 18XX Train
Snowdonia: The Lord Mayor's State Coach
Snowdonia: The Necropolis Railway & Neuhauser Bockerlbahn
Snowdonia: The North Pole & The Great Bridge Scrapyard Promo Tile
Snowdonia: The Siege of Petersburg / The Channel Tunnel 1881
Snowdonia: Trans-Australian Railway & The Daffodil Line

item.description:
Burger Battle is a card game of strategy & sabotage. Your goal is to be the first to build your Burger, but watch out! Other players will do whatever it takes to build their Burger first. Adding ingredients, taking them away, blowing them up or even sacrificing their own Burger to take you down!

To start the game, players will receive 1 of 8 different Burgers, each with different ingredients. To win, you must build your Burger to completion while keeping other players from building theirs.

During your turn, you will play an ingredient for your Burger and draw a card; This repeats until you can no longer play. Once your turn is finished, you can either discard a card or play a Battle Card.

Battle Cards add and take away ingredients, protect your Burger or blow other players' Burgers up. Some can be as simple as switching hands others can be as devastating as destroying all the Burgers on the table, including yours.

-description from designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: 1676: Miniatures Skirmish Battles in the Time of King Philip's War

item.description:
Pilgrim cavalry charges! Desperate attacks on fortified settlements! Daring ambushes! These are just a few of the skirmishes you can fight with 1676 - a tabletop miniatures game set in New England during the Native American uprising that became known as King Philip’s War.

The types of conflicts that occurred in King Philip’s War were usually small skirmishes that can be represented on a tabletop with these rules. You can play a native war party or a force from the Army of the United Colonies. If you want to add "fell creatures," magic, & (gasp!) European powers, there is a supplement available with these additions (Mad Dogs & Englishmen).

The core rules are provided in only 5 pages. They are simple & straightforward. Simple die rolls - using 6- & 8-sided dice - are used to resolve combat & other actions. Most actions have the same target for success, so they are resolved quickly.

You can use one of the pre-made "armies" provided in a second PDF (Part Two), or can create your own balanced forces using a simple point build system. Part Two includes unit cards, sample army lists, & all the tokens you’ll need. Alternatively, premade Unit cards, Command cards, & (Mis)Fortune cards are now available from The Game Crafter.

Both books are illustrated with photographs of figures from Brigade Games' King Philip's War line. With these figures (supplemented by those from other manufacturers), you can now easily field beautiful forces in miniature to represent the combatants.

So heed the call to arms! Your colony or tribe is depending on you!

name.value: A Formidable Enemy: Rules for Miniature Skirmishes in The French & Indian War

item.description:
A Formidable Enemy is a fast-paced skirmish game set in the French & Indian War. There are two PDF downloads included with your purchase: a 36 page rulebook, and a 45 page book of army lists and rosters. You can use one of the six premade armies, or create your own force with a comprehensive point system. The game has a historical "feel" through the use of Assets specific to different types of characters & units. Optional "otherworldly" rules are included to take advantage of some of the outstanding figures available for this period. Color photographs of figures from Conquest Miniatures, Eureka Miniatures, AW Miniatures, & Warlord Games, as well as structures by Acheson Creations (all used with permission) illustrate both documents.

Part One contains the game rules (summarized in a 4-page Quick Reference), Assets to personalize your troops (Abilities & Characteristics, Weapons, Artillery, Special Unit Members, Equipment, Vehicles, Animals, & Structures), Liabilities, Otherworldly Assets (including Divine Interventions), Templates, Markers & Tokens, & optional Event Cards.

Part Two contains brief historical information, Army Lists, and Unit Cards for the Indians, French, British, Canadians, & American Colonials. There is also information on Bears, Dogs, Zombyes, & a few other optional (but fun!) non-historical additions to the game (inspired mainly by figures from Conquest Miniatures). There are six sample armies, & information about how to create your own troops & armies.

Challenge your friends and be the first to catch the Sasquatch. This is a fast paced game where each player races to collect 3 supply cards corresponding with 1 of the 4 locations on the board. On a turn, a player may play as many cards from their hand as they like, then draw back up to 3 cards.

Supply cards, when drawn, are immediately placed face up on the discard pile. The first player to grab the corresponding territory totem wins that supply card.

Once you have collected enough supply cards you must move yourself and Sasquatch onto the correct location in order to catch him and win the game. Watch out, other players will steal your supplies, rotate the board, and other things to mess up your plans.

The Barmaid's Tale takes place in the Ratcatcher's Rest, one of Tinderbox's more colorful establishments, and features a game known to the locals as "Pass the Buck".

The game is introduced via a story a barmaid at the Ratcatchers relates in an interview, in an obvious parody of "The Canterbury Tales". The account details the exploits of a hapless party of adventurers returning to Tinderbox to face their patron after a failed quest. Needing to set an example, but realizing that even bad help is hard to find, their benefactor decides that only one of them will be held accountable. But whose fault was it? It's at this point that the players step in to, well, pass the buck.

The Barmaid's Tale is a simple ten-minute social strategy game of blame and bribery for 4-6 players.

Art Deck is a drawing game for 2-6 players. Players are dealt cards from a deck of instructional sentence fragments ("what do to do", "how to do it" and "something that makes it difficult") and deal out a starting sentence with one of each. (eg. "Draw eyes / across half the page / without taking your marker off the page.")

On your turn, you play a card onto the sentence, replacing the previous one in that position, and then contribute to a communal drawing, obeying the sentence's instruction.

The game continues until someone plays a "sign your name" card and signs the artwork, completing it.

Damsel etiquette will tell you that you can never really trust a knight to save you properly, but as long as your dragon needs feeding, you should let them have a go.

In the two-player asymmetrical strategy game The Damsel's Tale, the dragon is trying to alert his mother to the presence of a devious knight sent to steal from their ancestral treasure pile.

Now a day of discount sales across Tinderbox, the original "Ruby Tuesday" was so named after a famous quest to recover the ruby hoard of the Salamander King. This quest saw every adventurer in Tinderbox racing to equip themselves and be the first to embark on the adventure, making a lot of traders very wealthy in the process.

The Trader's Tale is a fast-paced trading game in which you compete to control the game board and equip your party of adventurers.

Zoot Suit is a speedy game of card matching. You have to get rid of nine cards by matching each previously-played card by suit, by color, by background pattern or with a WILD card. It's fast, it's fun, and it's a fantastic five-minute family game for kids and adults.

—description from the back of the box

You are a band of pirates returning to the port of New Providence after a season of plundering. It is now time to share the treasure. During the game, the players will share coins and challenge each other to maintain equity.

There are 4 kinds of coins in the treasure. Some of them are valuable to make you a rich while some of them make you have nothing at the end.
Every round, players will (1)draft 2 coins (2)challenge another pirate and (3)donate.

(1)Draft
Without peeking, the captain draws 2 coins per player from the treasure bag, then places them in the center of the table. Each player chooses 2 coins. Then, they place these coins in their loot bag.

(2)Challenge
Starting with the captain and going clockwise, each player must challenge another player to swap their bags. The challenged player has two choices:
a. Refuse, and let the challenger take 1 coin from their loot bag at random, or
b. Accept, and swap bags with the challenger

(3)Donate
Each player selects 1 coin from their loot bag and places it back in the treasure bag secretly in player order. The captain then passes the first player token to the player on their left, with this player becoming the captain for the next round.

The winner will be the pirate owning the most valuable loot at the end of the game. 
Scoring
• Gold coins: Each gold coin is worth 3 points.
• Silver coins: Each silver coin is worth 1 point — except that a group of five Silver coins is worth 15 points.
• Black coins: If a pirate's loot bag contains 1 or 2 cursed black coins, the entire bag is worth 0 points, no matter what else is in it. However, if the loot bag contains at least 3 cursed coins, then the group of black coins are worth 10 points.
• Blue coins: At the end of the game, the owners of Blue coins can decide whether they use them as Gold, Silver or Black coins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Challenge your knowledge with Timeline Canada. From the discovery of Canada to the last concert of The Tragically Hip with their lead singer Gord Downie, to win the game, be the first to correctly place all of your cards.

Combine this game with other Timeline sets for more fun and challenge!

Contents: 55 cards and 1 tin box.

link.value: Timeline: 60 ans de télévision à la RTBF

item.description:
Football Dice is an exciting dice game based around national football teams. There are 16 teams to collect.

In each packet is one team, and each team has 3 dice; a defence die, a midfield die and an attack die. All dice are different colours relating to the teams colours, and include flag faces and cultural references. You can play with one set of dice by sharing them but it is better with a friend with another team.

Once you have decided who goes first and how long you are going to play for, we suggest 2 minutes, 1 player starts by rolling their defence die. Then you just follow the commands on the dice, and just like in real football, see who can score the most goals! If you roll a "flag face" you simply roll again.

—description from the publisher

The Earthly Scenarios game probes how adventurous you think you are, and how adventurous your friends & family think you are with its worldly content on real life events, occurrences and cultural traditions going on around the globe.

Players take turns reading a scenario aloud to the other players and then the other players try to predict how likely the reader is to participate in that scenario. Example: There is a Bridge made of Glass in China, would you walk across it? Predict correctly and points are gained. Every time 3 points are accumulated, an Earthly Card can be drawn, which contain certain clauses on them that can be used on yourself to get ahead, or against other players to keep them down. First player to 30 points wins!

Intuition of your peers is put to the test, as the most instinctive player is the most likely to win. Best part is learning about dozens of interesting, hilarious & thought provoking facts along the way.

-description from designer

Cards Against Humanity is a party game in which one player reads a "fill-in-the-blank" statement from a black card, and the others complete it by answering with their funniest white card… which usually includes words or phrases typically deemed as offensive, risque or politically incorrect. Whoever has the funniest white card wins.

Cards Against South Africa is a localised version of Cards Against Humanity.

Welcome to CQB, a complete self-standing set of science fiction miniatures rules for depicting Close-Quarter Battle! Inspired by the combat actions of the United States Space Marine Corps and other units featured in Skirmisher Publishing's popular and bestselling USMSC FM 7-22: Space Boarding Operations universal sourcebook, CQB replicates gritty, intense, close-quarter skirmishes fought on board starships, space stations, and industrial settings of Earth’s colonial worlds.

—description from the publisher

Each player has to get his 3 meeples from start to finish. There is a colored track for each player and movement is determined by a die. Only the last of the 3 meeples of a player may move and only if it can get to a space that isn't occupied by one of the 2 meeples before it. The first player to get all 3 meeples into the finish space wins the game.
A large scale 18xx game by Federico Vellani, covering all or part of the 48 contiguous states, USA Game has seven scenarios, and maps in east and west sections as 1825 and 1829 were.
An 18xx game on the surface of the moon. Incorporates a few interesting differences as a result and is a unique map.

In this game, players use their die as a timer; this timer is fed by coins, whose values indicate the amount of turns it will take to trigger a score. Scoring depends on the facing of the tiles around the pawns on the board – which is constantly changing, since the tiles rotate on each turn unless they are pinned by the pawns. This way, dice and tiles are constantly moving in and out of phase with each other.

The game will be won by the player with the highest score after all the timers have stopped and there are no more coins left to feed them.
An 18xx game focused on the Northeast US, designed by Rich Northey. Covers New England and parts of NY, NJ, and Pennsylvania.
One of the 18xx games set in Japan, this one with a historically accurate map based on the island of Okinawa. Shorter play than most 18xx games.

"Are the stars unfamiliar here?" she asked, and the sky grew suddenly dark, the star's patterns alien and exotic. "This is the Wandering Sea. The gods have brought you here, and you must wake them if you wish to return home."

In Sleeping Gods, you and a friend become Captain Sofi Odessa and her crew, lost in a strange world in 1929 on your steamship, the Manticore. You must work together to survive, exploring exotic islands, meeting new characters, and seeking out the totems of the gods so that you can return home.

Sleeping Gods is a campaign game. Each session can last as long as you want. When you are ready to take a break, you mark your progress on a journey log sheet, making it easy to return to the same place in the game the next time you play. You can play solo or with a friend throughout your campaign. It's easy to swap players in and out at will. Your goal is to find at least fourteen totems hidden throughout the world. Like reading a book, you'll complete this journey one or two hours at a time, discovering new lands, stories, and challenges along the way.

Sleeping Gods is an atlas game. Each page of the atlas represents only a small portion of the world you can explore. When you reach the edge of a page and you want to continue in the same direction, you simply turn to a new page and sail onward.

Sleeping Gods is a storybook game. Each new location holds wild adventure, hidden treasures, and vivid characters. Your choices affect the characters and the plot of the game, and may help or hinder your chances of getting home!

Welcome to a vast world. Your journey starts now.

—description from the publisher

item.description: Monkey Balance Tower is a game of strategy, luck and skill for 2-8 players. Roll the dice and strategically place monkeys to build a tower in this challenge that is played on 2 levels involving colors and motor skills. Each player creates a new tower level until it falls. The player who knocks over the tower loses.

A Napoleonic Wars flavored multi-player campaign game for up to 6 players based on Avalon Hill's War and Peace, Blitzkrieg, and Diplomacy.
Each player is a major state on a fictional continent occupied by 5 other major states and 7 minor states. The players have force pools from which to purchase infantry, cavalry, naval forces, and naval transports, to gain control of the continent for themselves or their alliance.

A print-and-play game with 1872 one-sided counters on a 33" x 26" map, 30 Event Cards, 12 Reinforcement Schedule Cards, 6 player cards, charts and tables, rules, and even art-work for the box you store it in, as well as a ZunTzu gamebox to play online or even solitaire without printing a thing...
all available free, at Uhlan Games: http://todd.mainecav.org/lfm/

—description from the publisher

name.value: To the Strongest! For King and Parliament

item.description:
A new English Civil War set, called “To the Strongest! For King and Parliament.”

Battles fought using the TtS! rules can be fought with model soldiers, on a dining room table and won or lost in less than two hours. The rules also support huge battles, with several thousand figures and up to five players a side.

A grid enables players to completely dispense with measurement, and so permits the game to move along at a cracking pace. Miniatures can be in any scale from 2mm to 5mmm and based for any of the common wargaming rules systems. To the Strongest! games use a unique activation system driven by either playing cards or chits. This system introduces uncertainty to a battle; in some turns a unit can move four or five times, and in others not even once. The same deck is used to resolve shooting and melee. No dice, whatsoever, need be rolled!

The rules include terrain placement and points values to support those players who wish to play competitively. Numerous army lists can be downloaded, for free, from the BigRedBatShop.

TtS! Rules are written in plain English, with appropriate diagrams, sample lists and many examples of play. They are copiously illustrated with pictures of battles and beautifully painted miniatures. They have proved popular with veteran and novice wargamers alike!

The rules enable two or more players to fight battles on a tabletop to a conclusion usually in two hours or less.

The book includes 78 pages of rules including army lists, diagrams and numerous images of beautifully painted wargames figures and battles. It is printed on 130 GSM paper, with stiff card covers, and wire-O-bound so that it will lie flat on the table.

Description from the publisher

Under a vile curse, the forest is slowly dying. A few druids, last guardians of this green and endangered kingdom, answer the call of the helpless animals. Save the forest and become its protector!
 
In Nemeton, you have ten moons (ten turns) to explore the forest, create new potions, and summon the spirit of animals to earn as many reputation points as possible.

A player's turn has four phases — night, dawn, day, and dusk — then the next player takes their turn.

At night, the druid summons the power of the moon to grow sacred plant essences in the forest. The player adds a “Forest” tile to the existing forest on the “Moon” side. Once the tile is placed, the player checks if he can link it in a straight line with another “Forest” tile of the same type (river, clearing, rock or earth), in any direction. The player then places the resources of a certain type on the activated tiles.

At dawn, the player turns over the "Forest" tile he just placed on the "Day" side. He can now discover a path leading to a sacred place: an Oak, a spring, or a Nemeton. If it’s the case, the player picks the corresponding "Sacred place" tile in the reserve and adds it to the forest by connecting it to the tile he just added.

By day, the player will move the druid to take the proper course of action depending on the "Forest" tiles on which he is walking: gathering all the resources on a simple tile, creating potions with those resources near a Nemeton, or earning the trust of animals.
â€¨
Exploring the forest isn’t easy. When moving forward, a druid can use a power to take winding paths and change directions or enjoy a boost in movements that go in a straight line. However, the player will have to choose between resting and getting back the power to move forward or getting a triskel to earn more points.

If he wishes, the druid can use a sacred plant, the archangel plant, to turn into a crow and to fly to any "Oak" tile on the board. He can summon the spirit of an animal to obtain its special powers and then use them during a special move (swap a resource, find a shortcut, etc.)

At dusk, if the druid helped to heal the forest by successfully doing virtuous deeds, he puts his token on the accomplished goal, giving him one more resource as well as bonus points at the end of the game if he is the first of the players to do so.

Once his turn is over, it‘s the turn of the next player until all players have laid down their 10 "Forest" tiles.

Then the players must count their reputation points:
Each potion gives the points indicated on the card.
The goals show the number of points given.
The animals give points depending on the different streaks.
Each triskel gives two points.

The player with the most reputation points wins the game.

-description from publisher

item.description:
You are a sorcerers apprentice. You send familiars to the forest to gather ressources and with them produce magic artifacts or simply extract mana from them. But other apprentices are also competing for experience: who will display the best result?

in the magic forest is a mini-worker placement game, were you sent familiars (workers) either to gain ressources or to take one of three actions. Ressources can be used one-time or continuing, depending where they are stored.

2 to 4 players enter the maze. First to claim 4 pavilions and leave wins...but will the others catch up?

There are two sorts of double-sided maze tiles - fixed and variable. The fixed tiles are arranged in a static pattern, the other tiles are shuffled and laid around the fixed tiles to form a 7 x 7 grid.

In your turn, you have the choice of one of 4 actions:

 roll the die and move your counter the indicated number of spaces along the path
 turn over the tile your counter is sitting on
 rotate a tile adjacent to the tile your counter is sitting on provided the path you're on leads to that tile and there is no other player's counter sitting on the tile
 move a card from elsewhere in the maze to a gap adjacent to the tile you are on provided the path you're on leads to that gap and there is no other player's counter sitting on the gap you are filling




You need to roll the exact number to land on one of the 16 available pavilions and claim the tile (this is how gaps are created). Then you must be the first player to return to the gate with 4 pavilion tiles to win (and other players will be actively trying to block you).

—user summary

A fast-paced card game about the consequences of the choices we make. Your goal is to run a successful and sustainable business, sourcing palm oil products for supermarkets. Palm oil can be found in 50% of packaged goods on your supermarket’s shelves, often with devastating consequences for the environment. Build the reputation of your brand by bringing more responsible products to market, reinvesting your profits wisely, and winning awards to edge out the competition and emerge victorious.

On your turn, you'll have to outbid your competitors to control the sources of palm oil most valuable to your market. Match Source Cards to Product Cards in order to sell - hopefully for a profit. Each round plays differently, with various regulations and consumer trends to account for, and different awards up for grabs. At the end of the game, the player with the best Reputation from awards and profit will be declared the winner.

What if we really cared how our products are sourced? Would supermarkets, with all the power they have, start to behave differently? From farmer to consumer, Tradejack provides an overview of the supply chains that bring products into our homes.

—description from the publisher

This is a newer, Soccer Themed, version of the classic Farkel (or Farkle). Game mechanics are similar to original but special bonuses that follow the Soccer theme. Basically a Dice-Rolling Math Game with Football Features and Chrome. Good stocking stuffer gift for a soccer fan. G-O-A-L!!!

A print and play WW2 wargame for two players and solitaire that takes around half an hour to setup and play.

The game sets a small squad of British Airborne against their German enemies in a series of small skirmish scenarios. The game's counters (or chits) each represent an actual soldier with the gameplay being in the thick of man-to-man combat.

The game can be played 2-player with one player playing as the British Airborne and the other player playing as the Germans. The game can also be played Solitaire with the player playing as the British Airborne against the German AI. For gamers familiar with Solitaire wargames this game uses a random chit-pull mechanic (as detailed in the video).

The game is played in a number of Turns. In each Turn the player(s) randomly picks a Pull Chit from the mug and activate their Infantry. The Game Turn ends when all the Pull Chits have been removed from the cup.

The player whose Pull Chit this force belongs to can now Activate one Infantry Counter. In activating the Infantry Counter the player can choose from several Actions such as Firing against the enemy, moving, charging into close combat, applying first aid, or attempting to fix a jammed weapon.

Combat is simple and effective without needing buckets of dice. Players must establish range, line of sight and any modifiers. 
Close combat is particularly brutal and decisive with the playing be able to declare charges into combat.
Snap Fire is a defensive fire mechanic where your Infantry Counters can fire on moving enemy counters.

Finally, the game features a unique mechanic in the shape of Bravery Points. These can be used to force the enemy to re-roll a dice against one of your Infantry Counters, but should you loose you will have less Bravery Points for the rest of the game.

Solitaire Game
The Solitaire takes the key gameplay from the two player game such as Combat Resolution and Movement etc and layers in specific Solitaire rules, AI for the opposing German forces and special Solitaire scenarios.

The Solitaire game features a full and simple AI to handle the opposing force, that will take you step-by-step to which order the enemy counters should be activated and their actions.

Smuggles n' Snuggles is a 2 player strategy card game where players compete as crime families of bootleggin' bears in the 1920s! borrowing from classic playing card games, each card needs only one number. However, with a few simple rules, all your cards take on new roles as they move around the table - sometimes smuggling their fuzzy family members into rival territory or snuggling the competition with big ole bear hugs. Combining these tactics and letting each bear do what they do best will be the keys to victory.

—description from the designer

The Critical Mass 15mm rule system is a fast play alternative action company level game. Infantry are based in multiples and form platoons, vehicles are based individually and grouped to form units. Each game round players must manage their units activations with play continually moving back and forth as each unit is activated meaning games a tense and involved. As you would expect from a sci-fi game Walkers, Drop Troops, Grav Tanks, and much more are a plenty, coupled with lots destruction and mission defined battlefield objectives.

—description from publisher

Deep in the heart of the desert, from the far corners of the earth, Archeologists from around the world search for treasure from centuries past...

Treasure hogs is a competitive, fast pace card game where players take on the role of an Archeologist and compete to become the ultimate Treasure Hog. Watch out! Every turn is filled with surprises! Thieves lurk in the shadows and your riches could be stolen at any moment!

In Treasure Hogs, players use resources from their hand each having value ranging from one to three, hogging as many treasures as possible on their turn. The more value used to gain the available treasure, the less chance another player will be able to steal your riches!

Out of turn, you may use one or more Thief cards to steal the active player’s treasure. Once the value has been declared, if your thieves’ combined value is equal or more, shout “OINK!” to steal all the treasure the opposing player was attempting to gain.

When all the treasures are claimed, the player with the most treasure points wins and becomes the Ultimate Treasure Hog!

Treasure Hogs is for 2-5 players, easy to learn and can be played in under 30 minutes. Designed for ages 10 & up.

Aromat is an abstract strategy game that uses a mobile app for score calculation and score keeping. The heart of the game is the hexagonal game tile, consisting of shapes, numbers, dots and a player Emblem Sign.

You can play Aromat by placing the Game Tiles next to each other. Each special calculation created by the two adjacent sides of the Tiles following the gameplay rules either adds or subtracts a certain amount of points to your Game Score. The mobile app does the score calculation and score keeping for you.

Aromat can be played using Play Field Elements by constructing these elements before the game starts. It can also be played without, which requires more thinking because of the many possibilities present in any given moment during gameplay. Therefore it is recommended to use the Play Field Elements until a player becomes strategically aware of the many possibilities the game has to offer.

Research in neuroscience, human behavior and interaction and music didactics has been conducted in order to construct the methods and mechanisms behind Aromat. It contains beneficial aspects in terms of brain training and musicality training, which are achieved in a fun and engaging way.

Aromat is a collectible game that starts out with the "Basic Set" and expands through a system of "Extension Sets"'

—description from the publisher

What if everyone you know, loved, and remembered are just complex simulations in a computer-generated universe? What if you began to see through the shroud that separates what you think is your life from what is real? What if you wake up from this simulation, only to wonder if you are in another?

With multiple play modes for competitive, solo, or even cooperative play, what happens next is completely up to you. You can play the game in the standard Classic mode, the more complex Challenge mode, or the stretch goal based Adventure mode, which will allow you to match wits against a litany of enemies.

Compete with your friends in a race to ascend to the ultimate reality! Choose cooperative play to collaborate with your rivals or plot each others’ downfall. Or go solo and practice your skills at breaking out of the simulation.

The base game will include 3 realities, each with 5 unique characters. A 6th character per reality will be available as a stretch goal. Each of these characters has their own strengths and weakness plus a unique backstory which has a real impact in the Adventure mode.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
GAME SYSTEM

 
 
 This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.

 



The Patrol: A Coloring Card Game features soldier cards with unique artwork and abilities. 2 players split 5 Soldier cards into patrols to utilize strategy and a hide/reveal system to destroy their enemies. At the end of the battle, soldier cards that are still alive and face up receive a level(+1/+1). The player gains 1 point for each level gained this way. First player to 20 points wins the war. 
Players are also able to enhance each card with 12 different colors/abilities. Each color/abilities provides a unique play style and allows for the creation of unique decks for each player. Players draft their deck by coloring in their cards to pull from 1080 different combinations of cards.—description from the designer

link.value: Patrol: A Coloring Card Game – Power Patrol

item.description:
Niimura Station is a solitaire (1 player) game about running a small train station in Japan for one day. It is loosely based on the station of the same name.

Your task is to manage the needs of the travelers who pass through your station.

NOTE:
This game was designed as part of a 52 Game Design Challenge, which is a one year series of ONE WEEK design challenges. Including all testing. I can not guarantee it is balanced.

You have been warned.

The tiny diamond ring of Lisette Black, the beautiful doll has disappeared! The inhabitants of the magnificent dollhouse set out to investigate who, where, when and why hid the jewel.

Regardless of the number of players, eight dolls are used in this deduction game. In each turn, 3 action points are at the players’ disposal for diceless movement and/or other actions. They use a handful of cards to make assumptions and narrow down the possibilities through the reaction of others. The player who successfully identifies the perpetrator and all the circumstances of the theft wins the game.

This investigation/deduction game can be played by 3-8 players. Despite the dollhouse environment, the game is recommended from at least 8 years of age, but it is more suitable for bigger kids, and is challenging for adults as well.

The graphics of the game board and the cards are very special. They meticulously depict a world of 18-19th century dolls and dollhouses, the originals of which are parts of the amazing collection of the Hetedhét Toy Museum of Székesfehérvár, Hungary. The very first piece of the game was made for the Museum itself.

—description from the publisher (translated)

EltÅ±nt a szépséges Lisette Black baba apró gyémántgyÅ±rÅ±je! A pazar babaház lakói összefognak, hogy kinyomozzák, ki és hová, mikor, hogyan rejthette a páratlan ékszert.

A játékosok ebben a dobókocka nélküli dedukciós játékban nyolc babát irányítanak. Három akciópont áll rendelkezésükre, amelyet a helyiségek közötti mozgásra és/vagy egyéb akciókra használhatnak fel. Kártyák segítségével ellenÅ‘rizhetik a feltételezéseiket és szÅ±kíthetik a kört. A játékot az nyeri, aki hiánytalanul megnevezi a tettest és az összes körülményt.

A Rejtély a bababházban 3-8 játékos által játszható dedukciós, nyomozós játék, ami 8 éves kortól ajánlott. Annak ellenére, hogy színterét egy babaház adja, ez a játék kifejezetten a nagyobb korosztálynak szól, sÅ‘t a felnÅ‘tteknek is izgalmas, kihívásokkal teli játékélményt nyújt.

A különleges játéktáblán és kártyákon ábrázolt, 18-19. századi babaszoba-enteriÅ‘rök eredetije a székesfehérvári Hetedhét Játékmúzeum gyÅ±jteményének egyes darabjait ábrázolja; a játék legelsÅ‘ példánya is eredetileg a múzeum számára készült.

—description from the publisher (Hungarian)

This game uses the same cards as Marionette Kingdom but is only for 3 players while Marionette Kingdom is for 2 to 3 players.

One player distributes cards in a similar vain as in One Night Werewolf. The other players can only look at their cards, but can exchange their card with an (unknown) card from another player or a card that has been set aside.

Then cards are resolved, giving victory points or allowing to build buildings.

In the standalone game Carcassonne: Safari, players go out on a safari and try to see as many animals as they can, despite these animals hiding in the bush, in the savannah, or near watering holes. Help your friends to dig out such holes and receive bonus points. Sometimes you will see animals while taking a nap under a big baobab.

Carcassonne: Safari is the fourth title in the "Carcassonne Around the World" series.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Kill Team is the game of skirmish combat in the 41st Millennium.

Set in the same universe and using the same miniatures ranges as Warhammer 40,000 but with a different rules set, it allows you to play a game of fast-paced tactical skirmish combat in games of 2-4 players, in less time and with a fraction of the models you’d need to play a full game of Warhammer 40,000.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Cupcakes are at the height of fashion in the city. It's the perfect time to expand your business. Even though at the moment you only have one small Bakery, the dedication and the level of creativity of your employees means that there are no limits to your ambition.Your task will be no piece of cake since your competitors share your same goals and they are not going to make it easy for you. Only those who work the most efficiently and effectively will manage to build their own cupcake empire.

Cupcake Empire is mainly a dice game. Your personal board represents your business and the dice your workers. In each of the columns of the board you can carry out one specific action; create new recipes for cupcakes, open new stores, serve customers, hire new workers, etc. On each turn you will have to decide which column you are going to activate, taking into account that the more dice there are and the more specialized they are, the more effective the action will be. Through these actions you will increase your level of sales and production, trying to get them to grow in equal measure since at the end of each of your turns your Income will increase by the amount indicated by the marker that is the furthest behind i.e. that has made the least progress.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
It's a threequel of the award-winning deduction party game from the future — well, and from the past, too!

Get ready for an outstanding time, traveling across the brightest eras and countries! Expose a spy in a neanderthal cave or in a lunar base, hide out in a WWI Airship or in Leonardo's studio, and do your best not to spill all the secrets of the Japanese ninja or of a Spanish entity you surely didn't expect here!

Spyfall: Time Travel is a standalone threequel for Spyfall — an easy-to-learn party game that features bluffing, suspicion, probing questions, and clever answers. At the start of each round, players receive a secret card informing them of the group's location, except for one player who receives the spy card instead. The spy doesn't know where they are, but if they can figure out the location before their cover is blown, they win the round!

This game is fully compatible with other games of Spyfall.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
A card game of time and space, where quantum mechanics decides the cards you are dealt, but you decide the outcome. You now have the chance to craft powerful machines, use wondrous items and collect valuable treasures and artifacts.

The game can be enjoyed by both newcomers and veterans, and although it can be easy to learn, it can be tricky to master. Amassing the most points by the end of the game determines the winner. Timing and the choices you make can be the difference between a winning and losing strategy. Every turn is a chance to snatch victory from your opponents.

The game is themed in a steampunk setting with elements of futuristic to implausible designs. A quick-paced tactical card game for 2-6 players.

—description from the designer

name.value: Dark War REBOOTED Roleplaying and SKIRMISH Game

item.description:
A Simple Game
Dark War uses a simple system, based on a single rule. Anytime you role a 4 or greater you get a success. That success might mean you pump two AK-47 rounds into a werewolf, or that your nurse heals a team member, or a witch gains control of a weak-minded soldier, forcing him to fire on his comrade. What varies are the dice that you use. When building your own character, you assign a fixed number of dice (4 x D4, 3 x D6, 2 x D8) to seven attributes--Shooting, Melee, Speed, Intelligence, Charm, Will, and Dodge-- to determine what type of individual you control. The more dice and the better the dice assigned to an attribute, the greater chance you have or rolling successes. But the customization doesn't end there. You can use experience points to buy Kickers, such as "Rifles," which adds an extra D6 when firing a rifle or "Power of Prayer" that allows a character to heal a teammate within two squares. Two many options? Just choose a group of pre-generated characters from the bestiary, slap them on the provided map, and have at it. Or, if you prefer, you can fight out one of the three, included skirmishes

Obviously attributes such as Charm and Intelligence can be put to great use when roleplaying, but Dark War's unique Action Cards ensure they are relevant even when fighting a quick skirmish. For example, when an opponent activates a character you can slap the Fear Action Card on them, forcing them to pass an Intelligence test or lose all their actions. Other Action Cards can reload a weapon, add a die to melee, or even heal a wound.

When the fighting breaks out, characters determine initiative by rolling a combination of their Speed and Intelligence dice. The total determines when they act (higher is better, obviously) the number of successes determines how many Actions they have. Simple, fluid, and highly interactive.

Many RPGs say "Here are the rules, now go buy your own stuff to play with." Dark War is different. In each game you get the core rule book, 18 Action Cards, a 17" x 22" battle map depicting a West German village, and 70 1" square counters that include Russian and American soldiers, civilians, werewolves, vampires, witches, dead folks, zombies, and more. Better still we include a handful of stands, enabling the counters to functions as standees. It's like having your own set of Dark War minis. Furthermore, the rules include three ready-to-play skirmish scenarios (In the Beginning, Stranger Things, My Enemies' Friend) and a beginning-level, one to two session adventure titled, The Escape, complete with generated characters. When we say "Ready to play," we mean it.

It's a small unit skirmish game, it's a roleplaying game, it's straight-up fighting or weird war combat. It's whatever you make it. It's the Dark War Roleplaying game.

Frequently Asked Questions
Can I play the skirmish game solitaire? Sure, you just have to play each side to the best of your ability.
Can I use my own miniatures? Of course you can. You can use your own minis, terrain you have made, 1" square battle maps that you have bought, or even hex maps. Nothing in the game precludes that. The difference in Dark War and many RPGs is that you aren't REQUIRED to buy that. We give you everything that you need.

item.description:
RONE — Races of New Era — is a strategic post-apocalyptic card game for 2 or 4 players. Players are immersed in a dark world full of destruction and suffering, a world where people are fighting to take back their place after a global nuclear war annihilated all achievements of the human race and all that was left was only a handful of usable resources.

This second edition of RONE includes the core game, plus the New Forces and Awakening expansions in one box. There is new content as well, including features, new art, and add-ons. For back compatibility with the first edition, the cards are populated with an expansion symbol to easily distinguish which card belongs to which expansion.

item.description:
Jönköping - Spelet om din stad ("Jönköping - The Local Game") is yet another of those Monopoly-style games that Swedish Local Authorities love to commission from games publishers.

In this case it was Gothenburg-based games publisher We Are Sailing (now defunct) that created the game.

The game is about the modern Municipality of Jönköping (Jönköpings kommun), which explain why the towns of Gränna and Huskvarna is present in the game (included in the Municipality since 1971). Historically, geographically and culturally Jönköping (founded 1284), Gränna (founded circa 1690) and Huskvarna (founded 1911) is quite separate entities. Also, the isle of Visingsö (a former countryside council in its own right) features fairly prominently in the game.

The game is estimated to have been published in 2008.

War Thunder: The Siege is the classical cooperative Castle Panic game in the setting of World War II. Destroy the enemy troops in cooperations with your friends. There are no winners and losers. You will win or die together.

German troops are going to siege this strategically important city. The Wehrmacht is storming the fortifications the Red Army and the allies, and only you have the strength to keep the line. Can you destroy the enemy or you will allow him to wipe the city? Fight together with your allies and share the win or defeat!

Oceania is a family game about shipping and (actually) maintenance of ships. Palet spil co-operated with marine paint manufacturer Hempel's Marine Paint in making this game and the Hempel's features repeatedly on the game board.

The mechanism is the usual roll and move through a single track with some event cards added. Winner is the first to reach the destination.

An artist signature "Bergholm" can be seen at the box lid picture, but not on the game board.

The publishing year is estimated at circa 1980 given Palet ceased operations in the 1980's.

A game of extra-terrestrial antagonism for 3–5 players!

You are an alien! Your objective is to steal the Earth’s defense codes and conquer the planet.

In this fast paced party game, you must collect Intel cards from several search piles each with its own risks and rewards, the higher the risk the more likely you will gain the precious Intel but, try to avoid the Accident cards as they call attention to you and your plans.

Each player has access to a variety of Gadget and Sabotage cards to help them, or to hinder other players.

Collect the Intel, escape the secret compound and win the game, before you are discovered!

–description from the designer

Bull Shit is an incredibly exciting party game for 2 to 6 players.

Be the first to get rid of your seven cards by performing the commands dictated by the surprising 8-sided dice. Challenge your friends, match your bluffing skills to perfect timing and a healthy dose of luck, and who knows, you could be the new bullshitt(ing) champion!

—description from the publisher

The game takes place in 1667, after an edict signed by Louis XIV launched the construction of a canal to connect the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea. Pierre-Paul Riquet is tasked with coordinating this gigantic building project but he needs your help.

In the shoes of one of his engineers, you mission is to build as many sections of the Canal as you can, using available resources the best way possible. Players compete to measure the manpower necessary for each section and earn recognition from Pierre-Paul Riquet. But sudden reinforcements could change the game!

When the Canal du Midi is finished, the player with the most recognition points for the sections they helped build has won the game.

—description from the back of the box

Canal du Midi is a quick game played over 9 rounds in about 15 minutes. Players have 9 worker cards, representing varying amounts of manpower. Three of these cards are taken up into their hand, three are open on the table in front of them, and the remaining three form their draw deck. They also get 2 coins.

Each turn, a single section of the canal is revealed that is to be build this turn, and players bid a secret amount of manpower to help complete the section by playing one of the cards from their hand. If the total amount of manpower is enough to complete the section (i.e. beats the target set by the card), the player(s) who bid the most receive recognition points. However, before the section is awarded, all players get the opportunity to spend one of their coins to call up reinforcements. After players have decided whether or not to do so, each player spending a coin may draw a random card from the discard pile, and add the manpower on the card to their bid.

At the end of a turn, players draw a new card to bring their hand size back to 3 (if possible). They can draw either the top card of their drawing deck (blind), or one of the 3 open cards (which will get replaced by the top card of the deck). Play continues until all 9 sections have been built (or at least started, if the manpower fell short), and players have played all of their cards. Whoever has the most recognition points is the winner.

item.description:
The stars of the Korean children's television show Canimals are the pieces in a curling/shuffleboard style flicking dexterity game.

Two players select four pieces each from the following characters: Nia, Pow, Oz, Uly, Fizzy, Mimi, Ato, and Leon. In alternating turns, each player flicks one of their pieces towards the target at the end of the mat. Players score points depending on how close each of their character pieces are to the center of the target. After ten rounds, the player with the most points wins!
